Award.AwardTitle: TUES-Type 2: First-year Virtual Internships to Increase Persistence of Underrepresented Groups in Engineering: RescuShell and its Parent Company RescuTek

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is an expansion of a successful preliminary study that implemented and distributed a virtual internship for first-year bio-engineering undergraduates. The project is using a virtual internship to provide simulated work experiences that allow students to begin understanding the role of engineers in industry. The expansion will produce a virtual internship for mechanical engineering and ultimately will produce a suite of virtual internships for the core engineering disciplines. The virtual internships are based on fictional product lines of a parent company. The impacted students will experience a simulated working environment.

Specific outcomes of the project include an increased motivation to persist in engineering and an increased understanding of what engineers do. Through wide dissemination the program is having an impact on a large number of students at multiple sites. Project results will significantly increase the accessibility of internship experiences for non-traditional students and students studying in rural or non-industrial areas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The U.S. engineering workforce is not sufficiently diverse to solve the complex problems facing the U.S. economy, and there are not enough women and under-represented minority students graduating from engineering degree programs to increase the diversity of the engineering workforce. In particular, many women who enroll in engineering programs transfer out after the first year. Research has shown that first-year experiences of authentic engineering practice can improve retention, especially among women and underrepresented minorities. However, it is difficult to provide such experiences for students who have little training or experience in engineering.

To give first-year students authentic engineering design experiences and increase the persistence of women and underrepresented minorities, this project developed and implemented a mechanical engineering virtual internship, RescuShell, which was used in three undergraduate engineering programs. In addition, a first-of-its-kind course based on two virtual internships was implemented at the University of Wisconsin–Madison. In the course, students participate in the mechanical engineering internship RescuShell and the chemical engineering virtual internship Nephrotex.

In RescuShell, students play the role of interns at RescuTek, a fictitious company that is developing a robotic exoskeleton for use by rescue personnel in dangerous or demanding situations. The students are tasked with designing the legs for the exoskeleton. Students begin by reviewing technical documents, conducting background research, and reading research reports based on actual experimental data. After these tasks are complete, they develop hypotheses based on their research, test those hypotheses in the online design space, and analyze the results, first individually and then in teams. During the virtual internship, students learn about consultants within the company who have a stake in the design. Not all of the consultants’ requests can be met by a single prototype, so students need to decide what tradeoffs and compromises to make. At the end of the internship, student teams present their final designs and justify them to the company and their colleagues.

Throughout the internship, students receive tasks via email from their supervisor, a virtual character in the simulation, and they are guided by a design advisor who communicates with them via chat and email. The design advisor answers questions, facilitates reflective conversations and team collaboration, and helps students manage their time. These interactions are controlled by a combination of artificial intelligence and a live human mentor using scripted materials.

Based on research conducted during this project, engineering virtual internships help students learn important content and professional practices, improve students’ understanding of engineering design, and provide a first-year engineering experience that students enjoy and find valuable. Importantly, this project has also shown that engineering virtual internships help women students feel more confident in their ability to become engineers, which could help increase the number of women who persist to an engineering degree.
